title: What will  the internet be like in 10 years? - Quora

response.answer_text: I would like to see more free applications built into the operating system that provide mind-opening opportunities to the consumer-citizen. For example: Programmable Heuristics by Nathan Coppedge Some of this would be about making not just windows, text, and specialized material generalized across the internet, but also the ability to analyze and integrate with the user’s main motives such as making money and feeling fashionably intellectual. The simple commercial way to do this is to integrate education and Starbux with additional fantasy elements. Ideally this is most compatible with an economy that is doing very well. At minimum, there should be some public ‘installations’ or implacements similar in their role to ATMs which can provide special clues about how to live and improve one’s life, and how to use the local environment. This means smarter cities, more citizenship options, and short writings designed to benefit and entertain consumer citizens. I think the electronic paper revolution is a missed opportunity. It is possible to imagine lower-income people who could own one piece of electronic paper and engage in an intriguing personal education using these public installations. Right now the internet is not designed for standardized entertain-ucation, but it should be. One of the big opportunities is to cull the best examples of art and writing, and make them expressly available for entertain-ucation. If the program is good enough, people will be willing to pay small amounts of money just to get the best quality information and services. I think one of the keys will be to make cities more interesting, with public interfaces that provide a medium of exchange between businesses, government, institutions, and consumer-citizens. It will be important to have consumer functions and incentives which are not merely ‘official and boring’. The public interface should be tied into any free income and multi-tiered entertain-ucation programs that are locally or nationally available. An important key will be to use physical resources efficiently. So, for example, instead of buying textbooks or building a new building, the services will pay for a certain amount of electronic paper which can circulate and be re-used, as well as a public terminal that can update the electronic paper. If the writing is exciting or useful enough, like special selections from Nathan Coppedge’s writings on Quora, then there will be a big boost to the feeling of urban intellectualism which supports the belief in technology and the futuristic. The electronic paper and incentives can also serve a psychological function, preventing criminal and deviant behaviors or providing pop-up messages about structured community events. It will be important to be very sensitive to people who would not assume that a given event is important, or who would not assume they in danger of being a criminal or a victim of one. The resources can be used for mental adventures, and for giving people the right assumptions to avoid bad behaviors. It will be important to be very optimistic-sounding, intuitively deep, and stimulating. After all, people who are not interested in reading the material at all are less likely to be thoughtful and intuitive. The internet will partly be a communications service which performs some actions automatically, when they have a special benefit to the consumer-citizens. Things that improve optimism without destroying authenticity should be supported. There will be consumer options as well, but it must fit with the economic system. Perhaps some kind of virtual credit system could be used for people who do not have much income. Also, the internet of things will become more major, and there will be more opportunities to interact with electronics built into the environment. This will be an extension of things like public interface, electronic paper, academic computers, and terminals, but will provide general enhancement services like information and therapy, say to someone sitting on a park bench. Another option might be tasteful music or an explorative sound effect. Some of these services can be designed to be short and to-the-point in order to get the best results over time. Another aspect will be that there will be some high-end services used more rarely that allow certain citizens to buy into the economy on a consumer basis. Certain periodic outputs or information access is guaranteed in exchange for an initial investment. In this way, the economy can have more human structure, and such services should be designed to be low-commitment, and high-incentive. Another aspect is the way the new infrastructure works for corporations, institutions, and government. There will be more information available about consumers, or at least more information about consumer behavior, which is something businesses can act on. It will become easier and easier to provide high-quality services, and since services make things easier for the government, the government will have an incentive to provide infrastructure which benefits the consumer experience, whether that means more brilliant zoning (for example, my suggestion of combining hospital and resident zoning), additional services, or particular ways of integrating the environment with the consumer-citizen to make things more fashionably intellectual. In my mind the most important thing will be that consumers have something significant to think about. My suggestions are that there will be an elaborate network of philosophical and spiritual systems hooked into visuals, gamification, consumerism, and education. There will also be great new discoveries like the supportive city, space travel, and perpetual motion which will make future cities more vibrant and intellectually interesting. The future internet is just communication with visuals, and the various structured services and consumer functions which make education and citizenship possible. That is my vision. AN EXCITING NEW ERA IN HISTORY IS ABOUT TO BEGIN!!!

Over the next 10 years, I think, firstly, every website in the Web will become more and more like a web-based platform on which we are enabled to build contents, service, and applications and are also enabled to install applications, service, and contents. As a trend, web-based platforms might turn into a universal, standard, widely applicable website for delivery, like today Microsoft Windows is delivered to everyone and every organization. Secondly, everyone and every organization will have a web-based platform that is operated by themselves, like today they operate their own computing platforms (computers), on which applications, services, and contents are mainly purchased and installed from some stores. As a result, individuals or organizations can be relatively equivalent nodes on the Internet as big companies that have dominant public web-based platforms. The number of websites in the Web will become huge. Thirdly, web-based platforms can be connected together and built relations, like today computers can be networked, so that resources can be shared across websites. It means the Web cannot remain as just a collection of websites among which there are short of connections and relations. In other words, in 10 years in the Web, “networked” personal web-based platforms will take place of personal networked computers as more Internet-centric external information systems or even control systems along with our brains in the upcoming future.

The field of programming is very quickly improving and web development has seen many improvements in the past few years. There is a long list of choices of technologies you may prefer to learn. A lot of frameworks and libraries are created in past few years including jQuery, Laravel, Ruby on Rails, Django, Reactjs, Vuejs and many more. These additions have also made web development easier and added many new features. A web developer in 90’s may spend days or weeks to do a task that can be done in an hour or half today and some websites today are the main base of a commercial merchandise like Amazon. This was not even possible in 90’s. Now to see where we are going in the next 10 years… Well, I think in 2028, you won’t probably need to code anymore to build websites. A piece of software may provide an user interface using which you may add all the functionalities you need. There is also an example of it in the present. I am talking about content management systems like Joomla, WordPress, etc. Currently, these CMS’s lack the feature to add some functionalities and most of their code for specific purposes is written by amateur programmers. If some improvements are made to these CMS’s(maybe in the near future) it may seem like an end to the career in web development but I don’t think so. The point is, you may need to develop some kind of software or content management system like WordPress. More CMS’s may be created. If you have started your career in Web development, it’s a possibility that after 10 years you may be working in software development company as an employee for creating a new CMS that may provide users with countless features and easiness. Hope your question is answered….

In recent years, there has been a strong movement with all the emerging frameworks in which we try to find how to work and build web applications/websites easier and more efficiently. That happens due to the fact that web development is so open that you can literally build the same thing with limitless ways. That brings frustration and makes web development, a painful and time consuming process. I believe that in 10 years we will eventually have a couple of ‘standard’ frameworks/libraries in which we will heavily rely upon to develop web applications. These frameworks will provide everything you need to quickly build your projects from top to bottom with ready to use, extendable and customizable components that can work together seamlessly to achieve the functionality you need. Think of it like the Bootstrap framework but for your whole web application. This could enable us to build projects faster, easier and less prone to errors. It could also help us evolve the standard libraries for our own benefit and eventually stop reinventing the wheel. Of course, I don’t think that alternatives will go away and you will still be able to use different languages/frameworks in case they better meet your needs. To sum up, I believe that many tools/languages will still be available (much more mature this time) but we will also have something that we currently don’t: a few standard all-in-one frameworks that are universally accepted as great and in many cases best solutions for web development. If you are interested, you can also check out the following post: What is the Future of Front End Web Development? | CSS-Tricks Hope that helps ;-)

like i’d know lol. I can tell you for sure who doesn’t know. colleges. joking aside 10 years is a long time. I think it will ironically be more complicated and webapps will probably converge with desktop apps, If webassembly catches on we’ll probably see that convergence happen really quickly. we’ll probably make more use of AI, perhaps for handling database things, and more specialized AI as well. I think we’ll see a couple more experimental amazon go’s or hybrids of that idea perhaps where there are only 5 people working at an automated store. idk if you’ve heard of teh internet of things, but that will probably be a reality, and websecurity will be even more important than it is now, as a compromise, there is also a couple of devs I know working on an alternative to the internet as the internet the way it’s set up isn’t perfect. I think we’ll see crypto become more relevant as we enter an IOT world, and as the US currency drops in value slowly.

In my opinion, that gross necessity of social medias will cease to exist. I've been in internet since, i don't know, maybe 2000 at its fullest, and in every stage of it i've seen a lot of pages going down just because they had anything else to offer in their current time. Just take a look at them: social medias offers everything by a single click. Games, groups, band pages, videos, pictures, notes, a box where you leave a comment and a "like system", besides the chat, obviously. In my opinion, it was much better when you had to open MSN Messenger, a Firefox tab for Fotolog, a Youtube tab, and even the myspace system for music. Having everything in a single place just makes the experience a lot more boring, simpler and stressful when it comes to personal statuses about topics that might alter your mood. (Quora is a place for this, you ask, we answer and viceversa, and debates can be generated with total respect).Coming back to your question, i think that there will be a lot of changes beside the social medias, the only thing i can say i hope for the future of this, is the correct location of everything, everything in its own place would be better, at least for me.

My belief is that you’ll become even less aware that you are using “the Internet” and automation and efficiency will abound. You are going to see a huge shift in mobile services and real-time data impacting the way we work and live. Just like 4G brought about cool new services like Uber and Lyft, 5G will have a similar impact with things we haven’t yet “invented”. Security will need to be brought to the forefront of our devices and infrastructure. The data we produce individually will skyrocket and will need additional protections. Watch the mobile space!

You will think about it and you get it. Everything will be on fingertips. That era will have pros and cons. Actually you need to worry about it in all manners. Firstly you have to check the pros and focus more to do things that increase them. What pros? You can buy everything from your cell phone and don't need to worry about driving to shops. Speed of internet would be great. Possibly you will get free internet in all parts of the world. Connections will be more strong and easier to reach. Secondly you have to check the cons. It will destroy your health. You will stick to your bed. No more meetings. No more hugs and wishes. Smiles will be smileys. Ending Notes:I can write a book on it. Actually I believe people would have written it. Everyone have thoughts on future and predicting it by looking at the speed of growth in technology.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the Internet of Things (IoT), with Blockchain, Big Data and Advanced Analytics or Machine Learning, will transform the Internet, as AI Internet, Smart Internet, i-Internet, global digital brain, neural interconnected networks. The AI Internet is emerging now, blurring the lines between virtual and physical, changing the way we live, work, learn, and think, and impacting all our life, society, economy and industries, including agriculture, finance, education, healthcare, and government and defence. Artificial Intelligence - Internet Society Digital Future Report AI becomes a permanent feature in social media networks and online platforms, where algorithms are used to curate the online experience, to improve user experience over a social media platform, surveillance and compromise anonymity. AI and automation will have online influence on human behaviour and decision-making. Among the most visible internet changes, could be outlined Impact of AI on the Internet economy: AI presents enormous opportunities to create new jobs, new industries and new ways of connecting… Kiryl Persianov's answer to How will the internet change 10 years from now (the year of this question is 2019)?

The interconnectivity of different sites, shared logins. Sites load faster. Downloading has improved a lot. Amazon is a lot bigger. Everything is socially connected now. There’s a lot of intentionally wrong (fake news or facts) information being spread now days. ioT, the internet of things has begun with everything from my tv to my washing machine being connected. It has never been easier for most people to communicate with others anywhere in the world. Many countries that didn’t have much access are starting to get more availability. Most of my music is streamed now. Netflix streaming is kinda big, and in general I stream all my TV content now. Oh, and digital currency (Bitcoin) and so much more?!?!?!

I think the internet could be used to communicate with aliens if we are lucky enough to find them in the next ten years. But I can envision the internet being used extensively for managing the major advanced cities of the world and connecting them in unbelievable ways. Maybe roads become embedded with supercomputers which use the internet to guide you to your desired destination on Google maps with the help of a holographic line!

The main change I would like to see is not technical, or anything to do with cool features. Development and technical innovations will occur, you can bank on it. The principal change I long for is a cultural change, I look for people becoming more involved with creating new platforms, additional specialized social media alternatives. I hope people begin to understand the full potential of the internet for global freedom. We have allowed giant corporate entities to dominate, and this is creating the same scenario we had with the old ‘mass media’ - where a few owned the right to govern expression and convey ‘The News’-this resulted in the global population falling asleep and being hypnotized. So, yes, greater awareness of what is possible to create, more alternatives and a shift away from the monopoly of media control.

As the internet increases in speed and wireless Virtual Reality glasses go down in price. The internet will shift toward virtual interactive worlds in which you can buy, sell, make social interactions, either with other virtual users or with their AI Agents. Movies will become more interactive like computer games. Skype VR will allow you attend meetings in VR using your personal Avatar which may look and sound exactly like you on your best day. Even while you are connecting from homes are hung over and just wearing your bath robe.

Ten years from now, I’d like the Internet to be: More available and accessible, especially to people who don’t currently have access.Technologically more resistant to censorship (We’re rewiring the Internet for freedom. – David Robinson)Technologically and socially more resistant to fraud and abuse.

I’m pretty sure it would be much easier to build a website in 10 years time than it is today. Websites like Free Website Builder | Create a Free Website | Wix.com and Weebly is the easiest way to create a website, store or blog had made it much easier to create websites with their drag-and-drop system that pretty much allow any newbie to create a well designed website with dozens of capabilities. But if you’re talking about coding, new languages that aid the current scripts and languages maybe? There might not be that much change if you’re coding the website.

The Internet in the next decade will be faster with better coverage. Fibre based Internet is rolling out more globally which improves speedSatellite Internet coverage will improve in AfricaCellular Smartphone Internet coverage will improve with Google One (cheap basic smartphones). There are 3 billion more people to connect to the Internet.IPv6 Internet Protocol will allow all people and devices to have their own global IP address. This will help with security and applications.Cloud computing will help lower the cost of business startups using the Internet.

The truth is, no-one knows. No-one can "predict" the future for the next year, leave alone 10 years, especially when it comes to technology and the internets, where 10 years is equivalent to a lifetime. Would anyone have "predicted" the iPhone 10 years ago and said "you will be able to surf the internet, get driving directions, checkin at locations, use gestures instead of buttons..." when posed with a question   "What will telephones be like in 10 years?" Further Reading: http://www.psychologytoday.com/articles/200101/we-cant-predict-the-future-and-thats-the-best

What will be the future of the English alphabet 10 years from now? It will be exactly the same as it is right now. The internet is like the alphabet and the things that use or more accurately, based on the internet are like words .(Websites, Apps , Cloud etc) Where it used to be “Where thou art” it will be “Where are you” they both carry the same letters but look so different So while the internet will remain relatively unchanged. The way you use it will change drastically.

1.Convergence of the Internet and the physical world 2.AI(artifical intelligence)and machine learning. 3.New and evolving digital divides. 4.Increasing roll of Goverment. 5.Future of the marketplace and competitions. 6.Impact of cyber crimes and attacks. 7. The evolution of network standards. 8.Impact on the media, in culture, and human interaction. 9.The future of personal freedoms and rights. 10.Privacy, Security, and Trust. We really don't know what the future holds, but can only hope it gets better.

It will be augmented to everything in the physical world.  Your home, car, office, elevators, shops, billboards, television, radio and many other things will have some sort of an Internet interface layer and will seamlessly be connected to the cloud.  And apart from being faster, more powerful and having a greater footprint on your daily lifestyle, the Internet will somewhat look a little 10 years older and so will you.

Here is a post that I wrote a while back on my blog: Knowing HTML, CSS and JavaScript is Optional (http://vistabasic.com/index.php/2017/05/06/knowing-html-css-and-javascript-is-optional/) Smart compilers together with good libraries can go a long way to replacing human-written code. Partly, the pressures for change will be economic because it is much more expensive to have people write code than to have machines write code. And there will also be the need for faster development and modifications. Programmers are not good at refactoring large amounts of code whether it is HTML, CSS, PHP or any other language. Programmers can be replaced by automation just like any other profession.

Cynically, webdev won't exist because net neutrality and other anti-web initiatives killed it. On the other hand I would say if the internet is still fostering innovation, look back to what people were thinking it would look like in 2008, and how we probably have tech now they never thought would be here so fast, if they even thought about it at all.

As it did over the past 10 years. Lots of Ads. Lots of movie backgrounds. Lots of social "like" buttons so you can share what you do with people. We can dump more and more content into a webpage and run larger and larger programs. We will see the "app" generation turn into the "cloud" generation where everything is a web page rather than an installed app.

Within a decade we will have the next major enhancement of the Internet - The Quantum Internet. It will be used as a “broker” for secure transaction. The Quantum Internet coupled with the Blockchain (distributed digital ledger). Reference: Quantum Internet Is 13 Years Away. Wait, What's Quantum Internet?

It will become part of everything, not just electronic devices, but everything: be it your organs, your pets, your door locks, your plants.  How The Internet Of Things Will Rule Your Workday In 2020 [Infographic]

We’ll need to up the speed a lot. So, probably fiber optic to most places. There are other changes that relate to information search which Google will have to adapt to or become obsolete. We would also need a higher level of abstraction.

Almost every site will use some form of technology that’s considered cutting edge today, such as artificial intelligence, machine learning or blockchain. This may be in the form of integrated APIs from other services, but these three technologies are set to usher in a new era of the internet in which data is decentralized and every website is able to give you a truly personalized experience.
I'm not a fortune-teller but I can see more AI/AUTOMATED TOOLS in the future. This will filter out all the uncreative designer and developers and only the strong and skilled people will survive.

Mesh networking.Augmented/virtual reality will be seamlessly integrated into everyday life.AI personal assistants — we'll rarely have to search for anything — most relevant information will be pushed our way.
Exponentially. Too many things to list, such as online eCommerce, gaming, dating, cloud based computing/storage, IoT, Music/Video streaming… The list goes on, and continues to grow. /s/WP

I’m not a techie, but I remember when YouTube was a blip on the horizon. Now it’s a perfectly amazing online library of entertainment, documentaries, tutorials, lectures, scientific reports and almost everything else. The Internet in 2008 was already a highly useful tool for getting information, and that capacity has grown enormously. I also remember when craigslist first got started.
Very different - AI and automated tools will make the process easier and more competitive.

100% wireless. 100% human access Holographic visual interfaces I/O 100% global solar energy grid Human derived energy generation Distributed micro component miniaturization embedded in host/users animals etc Wireless power transfer
